The administration edict barring girls
from entering rooms in the new Freshman dorms openly violates the long
cherished freedom granted the Hopkins
undergraduate by the Gentleman's Code.
As demonstrated on the front page of this
issue of the News-Letter the action has
not gone unnoticed, even among the incoming Freshmen.
Dean Shaffer does not deny that the
Code has failed. He cites increasing lack
of maturity and failure to live up to its
principles as the reason for the change in
administration policy.
Certainly something had to be done to
ease the introduction of Freshmen into
the freedom of university life as practiced
at Johns Hopkins. Perhaps the decrease in
undergraduate maturity noted by Dean
Shaffer is a reality. But does the administration ruling constitute the best solution
to these problems? We think not.
The establishment of the Freshman

problem of indoctrination admirably.
However the institution of the rule barring
girls runs contrary to the chief asset of
the plan, namely that it provided for controlled assimilation into unrestricted university life without the stigma of limiting

student faculty camps of past years, this
year's camp was nothing short of boredom and disappointment. We feel that
several factors contributed to the poor

To begin with, those students who attended were not, on the most part, worthy
of the distinction of campus leadership.
Although two of the class presidents, most
of the Student Council and other organization heads were present, they had, in
general, little to contribute to the advancement of intelligent, witty and lively
discussion.
They were, in short, among students
who knew little about the real organization and 'spirit of this University.

Nine years, I believe you will agree, is a long time. In fact,

To be sure, the work would have gone more rapidly had the
shovel been invented at that time, but, as we all know, the
shovel was not invented until 1946 by Walter R. Shovel of
Cleveland, Ohio. Before Mr. Shovel's discovery in 1946, all
digging was done with sugar tongs—a method unquestionably
dainty but hardly what one would call rapid. There were, naturally, many efforts made to speed up digging before Mr.Shovel's
breakthrough—notably an attempt in 1912 by the immortal
Thomas Alva Edison to dig with the phonograph, but the only
thing that happened was that he got his horn full of sand. This
so depressed Mr. Edison that he fell into a fit of melancholy

friend William Wordsworth, the eminent nature poet, cheered

But I digress. For nine years, I say, I have been writing this
column for the makers of Marlboro Cigarettes, and for nine
years they have been paying me money. You are shocked. You
think that anyone who has tasted Marlboro's unparalleled
flavor, who has enjoyed Marlboro's filter, who has revelled in

Way of Life. Whether you love your work or hate it, our system

will always reply, "No, thanks. I better stay here in case
somebody wants a dog wormed." I mean there is not one thing
in the whole world you can name that Rex likes better than
worming a dog. But even so, Rex always sends a bill for worming your dog because in his wisdom he knows that to do otherwould be to rend, possibly irreparably, the fabric of
democracy.

Harriers Need
More Men,
Experience
By RON SPECTOR
"Well, this isn't going to be
one of our greatest years," commented
crosscountry
Coach
George Brown as he put the
team through their first day of
training.
Judging from the results of
the first day the team's chances
for this year appear to be almost
nil. So far only four men have
come out for the varsity. In
cross-country the first five men
count in the scoring. If a team
has only four men its imaginary
"fifth man" is counted last in
any meet. Unless the Jays can
come up with at least a fifth
man they are almost certain to
come out on the bottom of any
meet.
Returning lettermen Gerry
Miller and Mike Levin hold out
some hope for the harriers, as
does sophomore Conrad Gebelein,
who took a number of firsts in
track last spring.
The harriers will feel the loss
of lettermen Steve Haust and
Jim Fitzpatrick, who graduated
last spring. Lost to the Naval
Academy is freshman ace Mike
Henneman, who took first in
several meets last year.
Things are a bit brighter on
the freshman squad with three
or four high school lettermen
showing up for the first day of
practice. Altogether, "about a
half-dozen" freshmen are out
for the team, but the remainder
have had no previous experience.
The attitude of this year's
freshman class seems to be
epitomized by the freshman who
showed up for the first day of
practice to explain that though
he had run in high school, he
did not intend to try out in college because he "got too tired."
